executive_summary: The Construction sector ultimately grew over the five years through 2024, with recently high interest rates not fully eroding previous years' gains. Sector operators construct buildings and engineer projects across a wide range of industries and applications, so construction sector revenue tends to correlate with broader macroeconomic conditions. Prior to 2022, the sector benefited from low interest rates, providing an accommodative borrowing environment for both residential consumers and nonresidential clients. Rising interest rates have since stymied sector growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The COVID-19 Pandemic Had a Mixed Impact on Construction
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The COVID-19 pandemic had a mixed effect on the construction sector, with overall industry revenue ultimately rising in 2020 and 2021. Lowered interest rates and a general trend of people spending more time in (and therefore spending more money on) their homes drove an increase in the value of residential construction during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, driving construction sector revenue growth. The value of private nonresidential construction was particularly negatively impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic as demand for office space dropped as working from home became more common, reducing investment in nonresidential construction.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: High Interest Rates are Constraining Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Currently, high interest rates, meant to curb inflation, are stifling investment in construction as an increased cost of capital has lowered demand for construction services. Rising interest rates have particularly negatively impacted residential construction, as the rising cost of mortgage loans has decreased spending on residential construction.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Supply Chain Issues and Labor Shortages Have Hindered Construction
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The supply chain issues that came in the wake of the pandemic increased the cost of construction materials, including lumber, steel and other materials. This dramatic inflation of construction materials was passed along to clients, contributing to growing revenue over the past five years. Supply chain issues increase uncertainty and lead times on projects, negatively impacting operators in the construction sector's ability to operate efficiently. High fuel costs and driver shortages threw a wrench into the efficient transportation of construction materials. Widespread worker shortages had a negative impact across the supply chain for construction materials.
With inflation having shown signs of slowing, the Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates at least once in 2024, which will encourage construction across the sector.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Though interest rates are expected to begin to be cut in 2024, the process will be gradual, so high rates will continue to depress construction sector growth for a time. High interest rates raise the cost of capital needed for construction. Interest rates are expected to ultimately fall from their current heights over the coming years, but will not likely reach pandemic lows. It remains questionable whether mortgage rates will immediately lower in response to falling interest rates, especially as demand for housing outpaces supply. With many homeowners having secured loans at historically low interest rates in recent years, demand for residential construction will be lower in coming years as individuals are reluctant to move and give up their current rates.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Strengthening Supply Chains Expected Over Coming Years
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As supply chain issues continue to fade into the past, average sector profit will continue to slightly expand as materials costs fall and operators face a more consistent operating environment.

As the supply of alternative materials rises to meet current demand, the supply chain will become more reliable. A broad trend of nearshoring or friendshoring will also make supply chains more reliable. As extreme weather and environmental disasters, including wildfires, droughts and hurricanes become more common in coming years, global supply chains will face continued threats.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Federal Funding Will Support Construction Sector Revenue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The 2021 Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act will provide sustained infrastructure funding through 2026, supporting the construction sector. In particular, the bill will provide funding for roads and bridges, green power infrastructure, passenger and freight rail, water infrastructure and other projects. Passed in 2022, the Inflation Reduction Act will provide funding for construction projects meant to reduce the nation's greenhouse gas emissions over a period of ten years. The 2022 CHIPS and Science Act provides for funding for domestically produced semiconductors, which will benefit the construction sector in coming years. Already, the CHIPS Act and the IRA have contributed to a surge in US construction spending for manufacturing facilities that is set to continue in the near future. Long-standing federal, state and local housing assistance programs will continue to be a steady source of revenue for the construction sector.

Demographically, millennials make up the largest (and growing) share of homeowners in 2023, according to a report conducted by the National Association of Realtors. As millennials account for the largest generation in the United States and are increasingly making up most of the workforce (which supplements them with income to purchase homes), demand for residential construction is expected to remain strong over the long term.

industry_definition: The Construction sector comprises the construction of building or engineering projects, in addition to establishments engaged in the preparation of sites for new construction. Inputs for the construction process are purchased from both domestic and international suppliers. Key suppliers include other construction operators in this sector, manufacturers and wholesale trade operators. Markets for goods produced by this sector include residential, nonresidential and engineering avenues.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment includes the construction, remodeling and renovation of single-family and multifamily residential structures, which may include single units, manufactured homes, townhouses, apartments and condominiums. Demand for residential building construction is influenced by current macroeconomic conditions, such as the level of unemployment, consumer sentiment, household income and mortgage interest rates, which collectively determine housing affordability and the availability of lendable mortgage funds. Current elevated interest rates have caused demand for this segment to decline after a brief rebound following the COVID-19 pandemic.

This segment includes the construction, renovation and repair of industrial buildings, excluding warehouses, in addition to the construction of structures whose production processes are similar to those of industrial buildings, such as incinerators, cement plants and other nonbuilding structures. Key downstream manufacturing markets, including domestic semiconductor, automobile and transportation manufacturers, experienced disrupted operations amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Still, many manufacturing industries built new facilities or retrofitted existing structures with advanced technologies in an effort to increase efficiency in producing and shipping their products in recent years. The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, Inflation Reduction Act and CHIPS Act all include funding that supports this market segment.

This segment includes the construction, renovation and repair of commercial buildings and related structures, such as office, retail, hotel, agricultural and entertainment buildings. An increase in unemployment in 2020 alone as well as the longer lasting rise of working from home has drove down demand for this segment.

This segment includes the construction, renovation and repair of institutional buildings such as schools, hospitals, churches, civic centers and prisons. This subsector has experienced mixed as government stimulus programs wound down, leading to an increased reliance on private investment. However, this segment benefited from the passing of the Coronavirus Aid, Relief and Economic Security (CARES) Act, which has since expired.

This segment includes the construction, renovation and repair of nonbuilding projects, such as highways, streets, bridges, tunnels, water lines, sewer lines, pipelines, power and communication transmission lines, dams, hydroelectric plants, subways and other mass transit projects and other nonbuilding structures. The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act of 2021 will provide funding for this segment through 2026.

products_and_services.product_description: This sector includes new work, additions, alterations, maintenance and repairs on all new and existing structures, as well as the on-site assembly of prefabricated buildings and the construction of temporary buildings. As the value of construction has fallen first due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the broader economy then due to high interest rates, this sector has declined slightly.

This subsector includes businesses engaged in the construction of entire engineering projects, such as bridges, highways, tunnels, pipelines, sewer lines, utilities and dams. Additionally, this subsector includes specialty trade contractors whose primary activities are the production of specific components for such projects; the contractors that are included in this subsector generally perform activities that are specific to heavy and civil engineering construction that are not normally performed on buildings. This sector should see growth from funding from the 2021 Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act which was passed following a dearth of federal infrastructure funding in prior years and is set to last through 2026.

This subsector comprises businesses engaged in performing specific activities, such as pouring concrete, structural steel erectors, site preparation, plumbing, painting and electrical work, involved in building construction but not responsible for the entire project. The varied nature of this subsector's services has led it to remain level as a share of overall sector revenue in recent years.
The sector's activities that do not fall under the major categories of construction.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The value of private nonresidential construction includes new construction and renovations associated with all nonresidential buildings, such as commercial, industrial, educational and religious structures. The Construction sector derives more than 70.0% of its revenue from new construction.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast holds the most industry establishments. The size and variety of services provided by the construction sector means demand is spread fairly evenly across the population. The material nature of construction activity limits the geographic area in which any single contractor in the sector is able to effectively operate. As the most populous region, it follows that the Southeast has the most construction sector establishments.

The West is the second-most populous region in the US and is home to the second-most construction sector business locations. Most construction contractors operate only on a regional basis, keeping concentration down and leading to a more even spread of businesses across the country, largely according to population patterns.

California, the most populous US state, has the largest share of construction sector establishments. California alone has the fourth-largest economy in the world (compared to nations including the United States), providing plenty of demand for the sector. Beyond population alone, the state's large economy and physical size provide for robust construction activity.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Health and safety regulations require that workers wear protective clothing and helmets on-site and that safe conditions are provided for them, such as scaffolding, harnesses and ventilation. The Office of Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) enforces standards for construction industries. State and local building authorities assess and enforce this code.

Construction industries are subject to statutory regulations that cover building standards, pollution controls, competing land usage, disruption to existing businesses or residents and occupational health and safety issues. Compliance with regulations generally adds to the sector's underlying operating costs; in the long term, however, compliance may reduce an operator's exposure to litigation associated with faulty workmanship and workplace accidents, lowering insurance premiums.

Operators in the construction sector are restricted by environmental regulations, including those set by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). EPA regulations aim to minimize environmental impact. They cover waste disposal, emissions and materials used. Construction companies must adhere to these rules to avoid legal issues and contribute to a healthier environment.
Zoning laws determine land use and building types allowed in specific areas. They help communities maintain order and ensure that development aligns

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, indicating moderate barriers to entry.
The industry assistance level is low and steady, suggesting moderate barriers.
The competition level is high and steady, indicating moderate barriers to entry.

basis_points.basis_description: Most construction contractors operate regionally, diluting national market share concentration.
Established general contractors pose barriers for new companies based on accomplishments and word-of-mouth.
Attracting skilled labor is challenging for new companies compared to larger, reputed operators.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The large size of the overall construction sector prevents any single company from gaining significant share.
Most contractors operate regionally, diluting national market concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Computer-aided design software has been increasingly purchased by general contractors, in addition to other modeling software that enables companies to better forecast and plan for a project's costs. Larger contractors typically provide surety bonds as an additional level of security for the completion of a project as promised.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit has grown as costs have cooled
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The average industry profit margin has rose over the last five years as supply chain issues, which drove up the cost of materials, have largely abated. Moving forward, profit is set to rise as supply chain issues are further resolved. Still, contractors are expected to continue to grapple with labor shortages.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THE INDUSTRY FOLLOWS BROADER BUSINESS CYCLES
volatility_points.volatility_description: Since downstream demand for construction services comes from every corner of the economy, construction sector revenue grows and contracts along with general macroeconomic business cycles. For the construction sector, these cycles are influenced by movements in long-term interest rates, general economic growth, business activity and demand for housing (which is impacted by population trends).

The COVID-19 pandemic increased volatility for the construction sector as it disrupted the broader economy, driving up unemployment, driving down consumer confidence, causing business closures and creating general uncertainty. The supply chain issues that arose in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic added uncertainty to the market.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Most of the innovation in the construction sector takes place downstream in the construction process. Many current innovations involve making the construction process more environmentally friendly. Other innovations include 3D printed buildings, the use of robotics and prefabrication. Contractors make use of drones for inspections and site surveying.

There is some room for product innovation upstream in the construction process, which consists of subcontracting and management. Technologies, including building information modeling, can facilitate project management. AI can be used to streamline the preconstruction and project management processes, including by using large language models to more efficiently complete requests for proposals and using image generators in the ideation and design process.

FAQs.question: Does your company primarily work with residential or nonresidential construction markets?
FAQs.answer: The Construction sector comprises services to both the residential and nonresidential markets; revenue generated from the nonresidential market represents the majority of sector revenue, while the residential market generates the remainder.

FAQs.question: Does your company serve as a general contractor or third-party subcontractor on most projects?
FAQs.answer: The Construction sector includes companies that operate both as general contractors and third-party subcontractors; operators in building industries are typically general contractors, while specialty trade contractors typically serve as subcontractors.

FAQs.question: Have the volatile prices of key construction inputs significantly affected the sector?
FAQs.answer: Volatile softwood lumber prices as a result of bilateral trade uncertainty between the United States and Canada have hindered the level of profitability growth for small- and medium-sized contractors. Additionally, volatility in the price of oil, steel and aluminum has led to managing inventories of input goods to be a priority for the sector.

FAQs.question: Does your company make use of subcontractors to save on wage costs?
FAQs.answer: Operators in the Construction sector make varied use of subcontractors; a comparison of subsectors indicates that the more labor-intensive industries, such as specialty trade contractors, generally have lower subcontractor expenses.

FAQs.question: Has your company considered using building information modeling (BIM) and other production methods that limit on-site construction work?
FAQs.answer: BIM enables construction managers to view every aspect of a construction project prior to beginning construction, enabling industry operators to calculate minute details either before or in conjunction with a project.

FAQs.question: In light of increasing wage costs, has your company considered using new technologies to increase productivity or reduce total employment?
FAQs.answer: Advancements have helped improve the flexibility of construction, both in terms of design or cost effectiveness and speed of project completion; however, the sector's low average wages imply that the use of labor over technology is unlikely to change soon. Still, industry operators are trying to use technology to make work more efficient, including drones.

FAQs.question: Has complying with new energy-efficiency rules in various building codes driven up costs? How has your company offset these increases?
FAQs.answer: The new regulations themselves have been a source of increased demand in certain construction industries, such as drywall and insulation contractors, while driving up operating costs across other construction industries, primarily building industries.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met on and off the construction site?
FAQs.answer: Health and safety regulations require that workers wear protective clothing and helmets on-site and that safe conditions are provided for them; the Office of Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) enforces standards for construction industries.

FAQs.question: How has profitability shifted amid volatile operating conditions?
FAQs.answer: While profit varies widely among the industries that comprise the Construction sector, average sector profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, suffers amid uncertain operating conditions, including volatile input prices and demand for construction services.

FAQs.question: How does your company address seasonal fluctuations in workload?
FAQs.answer: Construction services are provided to a wide range of downstream consumer and client markets, minimizing the risks associated with downturns in any particular industry.

FAQs.question: Do you currently have a good relationship with building and construction companies? Do you have plans to expand into new markets?
FAQs.answer: Contacts within key markets enables strategic alliances and relationships with building and construction companies.

FAQs.question: What future plans do you have to mitigate any volatility to meet budget requirements?
FAQs.answer: Effective cost controls ensures that operators meet budget requirements. Operators aim to maintain purchase costs amid volatile input prices, in addition to leveraging the use of subcontractors to manage labor expenses.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain your skilled workforce? What incentives do you have in place?
FAQs.answer: A highly skilled workforce is of importance to this sector where considerable specialization is required particularly in the specialty trade subsector. Operators use subcontractors when necessary.

FAQs.question: How will historically low interest rates affect the sector? Do you closely track interest rates?
FAQs.answer: The yield on the 10-year Treasury note serves as a proxy for interest rates paid on loans. When interest rates are low, so is the cost of borrowing for consumers and businesses. A low interest rate environment spurs demand for sector services, while high interest rates do the opposite.

FAQs.question: How much do you work with public-sector clients? How can you leverage your previous work to help you win public contracts?
FAQs.answer: The Construction sector derives a substantial portion of revenue from construction services to the public sector. As a result, sector operators tend to focus on previous success on projects to win public contracts. Additionally, efficiencies and competitive pricing tend to win public contracts, which makes economies of scale important.

FAQs.question: How sensitive is the company to demand from nonresidential construction? Does your company do a lot of business in the nonresidential construction market?
FAQs.answer: The value of private nonresidential construction includes new construction and renovations associated with all nonresidential buildings, including commercial, industrial, educational and religious structures. Operators in the Construction sector derive a significant portion of revenue from the nonresidential construction market.
